assetIdentification.assetDescription: The Camera System Integration function manages and processes video data from multiple vehicle cameras (rear view, surround view, driver monitoring) to provide situational awareness information to the driver and to various driver assistance functions. It handles camera feed selection, processing, and display to appropriate vehicle systems, enabling features such as parking assistance, lane keeping, collision avoidance, and driver monitoring.

cybersecurityProperties.goal: Ensure camera feeds, calibration data, and processing results cannot be manipulated or falsified
Ensure critical camera functions remain available during safety-relevant operations
Protect sensitive driver monitoring data and prevent unauthorized access to camera feeds

threatScenarios.title: Camera Feed Manipulation
threatScenarios.description: An attacker manipulates camera feeds by injecting falsified visual data or modifying legitimate camera data being transmitted to display systems or ADAS functions, potentially causing incorrect driving decisions
attackVectors: Manipulation of communication between cameras and image processing systems
Compromise of vision processing unit to inject false visual data
Exploitation of software vulnerabilities in image processing algorithms
attackSteps: Gain access to vehicle network (physical or remote entry point)
Identify and analyze camera data transmission protocols
Develop method to inject or modify visual data in transit
Create convincing falsified visual information (hiding obstacles, creating fake objects, etc.)
Maintain attack while avoiding detection through timing and data consistency

controlFlaws: Insufficient authentication of camera data sources
Lack of data integrity verification for visual information
Inadequate validation of processed visual information against other sensors
Missing correlation checks between sequential frames
unsafeControlActions: Display shows misleading environmental information (hidden obstacles, phantom objects)
ADAS systems make incorrect decisions based on manipulated visual data
Warning systems fail to alert driver to actual hazards
lossScenarios: Vehicle collides with obstacle that was hidden in manipulated camera feed
Driver makes unsafe maneuver based on falsified visual information
ADAS system fails to respond to actual hazard due to manipulated visual data

threatScenarios.title: Camera System Denial of Service
threatScenarios.description: An attacker disrupts the availability of camera systems when needed for critical operations such as reversing and parking, preventing the driver from receiving necessary visual information
attackVectors: Resource exhaustion attacks against vision processing unit
Flooding the vehicle network with high-priority messages
Targeted manipulation of camera hardware interfaces
Exploitation of software vulnerabilities to crash camera subsystems
attackSteps: Gain access to vehicle networks or systems
Identify camera system components and their dependencies
Execute attack to disrupt camera data flow or processing
Maintain attack to prevent recovery of camera functionality during critical operations

controlFlaws: Insufficient resource management in vision processing systems
Lack of isolation between critical and non-critical camera functions
Inadequate redundancy or fallback mechanisms
Ineffective error detection and recovery processes
unsafeControlActions: Camera systems fail to provide visual information during critical maneuvers
Display freezes or goes blank during reversing or parking
ADAS functions dependent on camera input become unavailable
lossScenarios: Driver performs reversing maneuver without visual assistance, leading to collision
Driver is unable to complete parking operation safely due to lack of visual guidance
ADAS functions fail during critical situations requiring camera input

threatScenarios.title: Calibration Parameter Tampering
threatScenarios.description: An attacker modifies camera calibration parameters, causing distorted visual information, incorrect distance measurements, or misaligned overlay graphics that mislead the driver
attackVectors: Unauthorized access to calibration storage systems
Manipulation of calibration data during service or update processes
Exploitation of diagnostic interfaces to modify calibration parameters
attackSteps: Gain access to systems storing calibration data (physical or remote)
Locate and analyze calibration parameter storage
Modify calibration parameters to create subtle but dangerous distortions
Ensure modifications persist across system restarts or checks

controlFlaws: Insufficient protection of stored calibration parameters
Lack of verification of calibration data integrity during startup
Inadequate validation of calibration consistency across camera systems
Missing detection mechanisms for calibration drift or tampering
unsafeControlActions: Display shows distorted perspective or incorrect distances
Overlay guidance graphics (parking lines, distance markers) are misaligned
ADAS systems make incorrect distance calculations based on miscalibrated data
lossScenarios: Driver misjudges distance to obstacles due to distorted visual information
Vehicle collides with object due to incorrect distance perception
Driver makes improper maneuvers due to misaligned guidance graphics

threatScenarios.title: Driver Monitoring Data Exfiltration
threatScenarios.description: An attacker extracts sensitive data from the driver monitoring camera, potentially exposing biometric information, behavior patterns, or other personal data of the vehicle occupants
attackVectors: Unauthorized access to driver monitoring data storage
Interception of data during transmission to processing systems
Exploitation of telematics or connectivity systems to exfiltrate data
Compromise of in-vehicle systems with access to driver monitoring functions
attackSteps: Gain access to vehicle systems storing or processing driver monitoring data
Locate and extract driver monitoring camera data streams or storage
Bypass data protection mechanisms
Exfiltrate data through available communication channels

controlFlaws: Insufficient encryption of sensitive driver monitoring data
Inadequate access controls for driver data
Excessive data retention beyond necessary operational periods
Lack of data minimization in processing driver monitoring information
unsafeControlActions: System allows unauthorized access to driver monitoring data
System transmits or stores driver information without adequate protection
System retains identifiable driver information longer than necessary
lossScenarios: Driver biometric information is exposed, enabling identity theft
Driver behavior patterns are revealed, compromising privacy
Cabin interior video is extracted, exposing personal activities

threatScenarios.title: False Object Injection for ADAS Activation
threatScenarios.description: An attacker injects false objects or hazards into camera feeds, causing unwarranted activation of automatic emergency braking, evasive steering, or other ADAS interventions
attackVectors: Manipulation of object detection algorithms or data
Injection of falsified object data into ADAS decision processes
Exploitation of vulnerabilities in sensor fusion systems
Compromise of vision processing units to generate phantom objects
attackSteps: Gain access to vehicle systems processing camera data for ADAS
Identify object detection and classification processes
Develop methods to generate convincing phantom objects or hazards
Inject falsified object data at critical moments to trigger ADAS responses

controlFlaws: Insufficient validation of detected objects across multiple sensors
Inadequate plausibility checks for object detection
Missing correlation of camera data with other sensor types
Lack of verification steps before initiating emergency interventions
unsafeControlActions: ADAS system performs emergency braking for non-existent obstacles
System initiates evasive steering maneuvers without actual hazards
Multiple false activations cause driver to ignore or disable safety systems
lossScenarios: Sudden unexpected braking causes rear-end collision from following vehicle
Evasive steering maneuver leads to loss of control or collision with other vehicles
Driver disables ADAS due to false activations, losing protection for genuine emergencies

threatAssessment.feasibilityJustification: Manipulating camera feeds requires specialized knowledge of automotive vision systems and access to the vehicle network. The technical complexity of creating convincing visual manipulations without triggering detection systems is significant. Physical access or proximity is typically needed initially, though remote attacks through connected systems may be possible in some configurations.
vulnerabilities: Lack of cryptographic authentication for camera data streams
Insufficient validation of visual data consistency and plausibility
Inadequate cross-checking between different sensor inputs
Limited frame-to-frame consistency verification
existingControls: Basic input validation for camera data streams
Some plausibility checks on visual information
Limited sensor fusion with other sensor types
Error detection for corrupted image data

threatAssessment.feasibilityJustification: Denial of service attacks against camera systems are generally easier to execute than sophisticated manipulation attacks. Once access to the vehicle network is achieved, overloading processing systems or corrupting data flows requires less specialized knowledge. Such attacks could be particularly effective during critical operations when cameras are most needed.
vulnerabilities: Insufficient resource protection in vision processing systems
Limited redundancy in camera data pathways
Inadequate isolation of critical camera functions
Weak recovery mechanisms after system disruption
existingControls: Basic watchdog timers for system recovery
Some error handling for system faults
Limited resource monitoring in processing units
Basic network traffic filtering

threatAssessment.feasibilityJustification: Modifying calibration parameters requires understanding of camera calibration processes and access to storage systems. While the attack complexity is high due to the specialized knowledge required, the effects can be subtle and difficult to detect immediately, making this attack potentially effective despite its complexity.
vulnerabilities: Insufficient protection of calibration parameter storage
Inadequate verification of calibration data integrity
Limited validation of calibration consistency
Missing detection of calibration tampering
existingControls: Basic access controls for diagnostic functions
Limited validation of calibration parameter ranges
Some logging of calibration changes
Factory calibration reference data

threatAssessment.feasibilityJustification: Extracting driver monitoring data requires access to in-vehicle systems and bypassing data protection mechanisms. While the attack has high complexity due to the need to locate and extract sensitive data, the potential privacy impact makes this a concerning threat, especially as driver monitoring systems become more sophisticated and collect more personal data.
vulnerabilities: Insufficient encryption of driver monitoring data
Inadequate access controls for sensitive data storage
Excessive data retention periods
Limited protection of data transmission channels
existingControls: Basic access restrictions for system storage
Some data anonymization practices
Limited encryption of stored data
Access logging for sensitive functions

threatAssessment.feasibilityJustification: Injecting false objects to trigger ADAS interventions requires deep understanding of object detection algorithms and ADAS decision processes. While technically complex, the severe safety implications of unexpected vehicle interventions at speed make this a high-priority threat. Successful attacks could cause accidents or undermine trust in safety systems.
vulnerabilities: Insufficient cross-validation across multiple sensor types
Limited plausibility checks in object detection
Inadequate verification steps before emergency interventions
Weak protection of object detection processing pipelines
existingControls: Basic sensor fusion with radar/lidar in some configurations
Limited object verification through multiple frames
Some plausibility checking for detected objects
Intervention thresholds requiring high confidence levels

keyTerms.ADAS: Advanced Driver Assistance Systems - electronic systems that assist drivers in driving and parking functions
keyTerms.Surround View: 360-degree view around the vehicle created by combining multiple camera feeds
keyTerms.Driver Monitoring: System that tracks driver attention, gaze, and alertness using an interior-facing camera
keyTerms.Calibration Parameters: Settings that ensure camera images are properly aligned and distances are accurately represented
keyTerms.CVSS: Common Vulnerability Scoring System - standardized method for rating the severity of security vulnerabilities
keyTerms.STPA: Systems-Theoretic Process Analysis - hazard analysis technique for complex systems
keyTerms.Attack Vector: Method or path used by an attacker to gain access to a target system
keyTerms.Attack Feasibility: Assessment of how practical and realistic a threat scenario is for an attacker to execute
keyTerms.Sensor Fusion: Combining data from multiple sensors to improve detection accuracy and reliability

contentSummary: This TARA Threat Scenarios document identifies and analyzes five key threat scenarios affecting the Camera System Integration function: (1) Camera Feed Manipulation - falsification of visual data leading to incorrect driving decisions; (2) Camera System Denial of Service - disruption of camera availability during critical operations like reversing; (3) Calibration Parameter Tampering - modification of camera calibration causing distorted visual information; (4) Driver Monitoring Data Exfiltration - unauthorized access to sensitive driver monitoring data; and (5) False Object Injection for ADAS Activation - causing unwarranted emergency interventions through falsified visual hazards. Each threat scenario is analyzed in depth, including attack vectors, attack steps, and STPA-based analysis of control flaws, unsafe control actions, and resulting loss scenarios. The feasibility assessment rates the scenarios using CVSS, with False Object Injection rated highest severity due to its potential to cause accidents through unexpected vehicle interventions. The document identifies specific vulnerabilities and existing controls for each threat scenario, providing a comprehensive foundation for subsequent risk assessment and security control definition.
